page.title: 18Nature Reserve, Hadstock
page.content: A small plot of land, about 1 hectare in area, on the edge of the old Liitle Walden airfield, is managed as the Harrison Sayer nature reserve. (It is named after the former owner of the land.) The reserve includes an abandoned stretch of the old road from Little Walden to Hadstock, and the founda- tions of airfield buildings, as well as more natural clay and chalk soil. It has a colony of bee orchids, though these don't grow in such numbers as they once did; hairy-leaved rose and wild liquorice also flourish. A vixen and her cubs usually have an earth there, and there are plenty of rabbits. Forty different kinds of beetle were counted recently. One of the wardens' jobs is to try to stop the blackthorn from growing over too much of the reserve.
